Re ''Bloomberg Draws a 25-Year Blueprint for a Greener City'' (news article, April 23):
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's plan for a greener and more sustainable city is important and potentially transformative for New York.

Transformations of life in the city have emerged from moments of economic, social or environmental crises such as the water shortages, fires and plagues of the 1830s, or the Moses-era ambition to meet the demands of building a modern and more economically productive city. Dramatic changes take place at times when most New Yorkers, along with a reform-minded business elite, feel that the city needs a radical new direction to thrive.

It is ironic that the relative economic prosperity that the Bloomberg administration has helped to foster, and its highly professional and at times socially detached, managerial approach to governance, might dampen the sense of urgency and connection that people feel toward the mayor's vision.
If the past is any judge, these conditions will make it more difficult to overcome the political hurdles ahead for making the plan a reality.
William D. Solecki Interim Director, CUNY Institute for Sustainable Cities New York, April 23, 2007
